title: Pentagon Issues Broad List of Projects at Risk of Cuts for Border Wall-but Hedges on Details
summary: House Appropriations Committee spokesman calls list 'wholly insufficient'. WASHINGTON-The Defense Department late Monday released a broad list of the possible projects whose funding might be diverted to build a wall along the border with Mexico, but it didn't reflect any final decisions about which projects would be delayed.

title: Trump Administration Officials Clash Over Relief for Venezuelan Immigrants
summary: White House deadlocked on fate of 70,000 Venezuelans in the U.S. as it weighs next steps to pressure regime. WASHINGTON-As an embattled Nicolás Maduro clings to power in Venezuela, the Trump administration has deadlocked over one of its remaining options for bolstering the opposition and pressuring Mr. Maduro, according to American officials and an administration email exchange.

title: U.S. Chip Makers Fear Trap in a Trade Deal With China
summary: Proposed stepped-up purchases would give Beijing more control, semiconductor industry says. WASHINGTON-U.S. semiconductor companies want no part of any trade deal that calls for stepped-up purchases from China, worried that would give Beijing more control over their industry.

title: Beto's Apology Tour
summary: The identity left is carving him up like a Texas steak before he gets to Donald Trump..

title: Limiting Too Big to Fail
summary: The feds narrow the rules for naming firms 'systemically important.'. Congress should rewrite the law, but at least the Trump Administration is now trying to reduce arbitrary rule-making by offering clearer standards for the Financial Stability Oversight Council.

title: Warner Bros. CEO to Step Down Amid Probe Into Conduct
summary: The exit comes as the company investigates a report of improper conduct. title: Supreme Court to Examine Insanity Defense, Need for Jury Unanimity
summary: Cases for next term to consider key questions of criminal law, including juvenile sentencing. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court said Monday it would consider whether two pillars of criminal law-the insanity defense and the rule that only unanimous juries may convict-are required by the Constitution.

title: The Jew Who Died for Ilhan Omar
summary: Lawrence Freedman went to Somalia in 1992 as part of the U.S.-led relief effort.. Rep. Ilhan Omar, a freshman Democrat from Minnesota, has become widely known for her attacks on supporters of Israel. Ms. Omar is a naturalized citizen whose Somali refugee family settled in the U.S. when she was a teenager. Tens of thousands of Somali refugees relocated to the U.S.-some 25,000 in the Minneapolis area-to escape the starvation, famine and civil war that turned Somalia into a lawless, failed state in the early 1990s.

title: 'Loonshots' Review: In Praise of Wild Ideas
summary: Innovative proposals can be both imperfect and discomﬁting-and are often rejected before they can develop enough to prove themselves viable.. As the possibility of war loomed in the late 1930s, Vannevar Bush-an academic engineer with strong ties to Navy research-was alarmed by what he saw: a military preparing to fight the next war with the weapons of the preceding one and little apparent ability to develop the technologies that he thought would be essential for victory. He persuaded President Roosevelt in 1940 to launch a radical new organization, ultimately named the Office of Scientific Research and Development, to cultivate fresh ideas and shepherd them into practical application. Technologies nurtured by the OSRD, including radar and the atomic bomb, would prove pivotal to the U.S. war effort.

title: New York City Picks Team to Develop Broadway Triangle Sites
summary: Team includes community organizations that filed suit in 2009 accusing city of racial discrimination in previous plan for site. New York City's housing development agency has selected a joint venture that includes community organizations to build hundreds of affordable apartments on an undeveloped swath in Brooklyn that had been at the center of an eight-year legal battle over racial and housing discrimination.

title: Triggered by Weinstein's Harvard Lawyer
summary: A law professor agrees to represent an unpopular client, and undergrads say they're traumatized.. Harvard has opened an investigation into law professor Ronald Sullivan, who earlier this year joined Harvey Weinstein's criminal-defense team. Some undergraduates complained that Mr. Sullivan's decision to represent Mr. Weinstein, who is charged with rape in New York, puts them at risk. By taking the complaint seriously, Harvard puts its commitment to identity politics above the core tenets of due process.

title: Iran-Backed Militias Step Up the Battle in Iraq
summary: A novelist's assassination, the harassment of a U.S. Army patrol and other signs of a growing threat.. Iran-backed Shiite militias in Iraq are growing more powerful and confident as they operate with increasing impunity.

title: Banishing Profit Is Bad for Your Health
summary: The Medicare for All proposal from House Democrats follows New York state's bad example.. House Democrats' new Medicare for All bill asserts "a moral imperative . . . to eliminate profit from the provision of health care." The legislation specifies that federal health funding-virtually all health funding if the bill were to become law-may not be used for "the profit or net revenue of the provider." That makes it more radical and less realistic than even Bernie Sanders' plan.

title: Retrial in Slaying of Queens Jogger Begins
summary: Prosecutors point to DNA identification, while defense portrays coerced confession. After Karina Vetrano was killed while jogging in a secluded park in Queens, investigators analyzed DNA samples from her skin, fingernails and cellphone. The DNA all matched an unnamed assailant who investigators called Male Donor A.

summary: Support for caps reflects criticism that unlimited borrowing by graduate students and parents of undergrads allows schools to charge higher prices. title: The Costs of California's One-Party State
summary: Progressives have complete control of Sacramento, but at least people can leave for other states.. I am a third-generation, middle-aged Californian and couldn't agree more with Charles Kesler and his astute depiction of the destruction of this once Golden State and its desire to push an impossible agenda of government largess for all ("California Has Become the Far Left Coast," op-ed, March 7). I see no good future for anyone in California thanks to the current political environment. It is sad to see this in a state where my grandparents and parents were able to make a go with their businesses with nothing more than ambition and hard work and no government to get in their way. Even farming, something my husband has been involved in all his entire adult life is becoming more and more arduous as the Legislature tries to run the only true environmentalists out of the state. If farmers don't truly care and understand how to care for the land and environment, then no one does.

title: Localities Deserve a Role in Opioid Litigation
summary: We look forward to working with our state and local partners as we hold the drug companies accountable for breaking the law.. Regarding George Jepsen and Perry Zinn Rowthorn's "Leave Opioid Lawsuits to State Attorneys General" (op-ed, March 4): Instead of promoting a united front of state and local governments working together to hold drug companies accountable for their role in our nation's opioid crisis, the authors suggest that cities and counties should stand back while our neighborhoods suffer the consequences.

title: AT&T Not Funding Groups Opposed to Sprint Merger
summary: AT&T is not funding Consumer Choice Alliance or Protect America's Wireless in their opposition to the proposed merger of T-Mobile and Sprint, or in any other matter.. Regarding Holman Jenkins's "Biggest Threat to 5G is the D.C. Swamp" (Business World, March 9): AT&T is not funding Consumer Choice Alliance or Protect America's Wireless in their opposition to the proposed merger of T-Mobile and Sprint, or in any other matter. Mr. Jenkins's suggestion otherwise appears to be based in part on misleading information from OpenSecrets.org. We have asked OpenSecrets.org to correct its website in this regard.

title: Planned Parenthood Replies to Sasse and McCain on Abortion
summary: There is no such thing as infanticide in medical care-I can tell you, as a doctor, that it doesn't happen and it is already illegal.. I am deeply disturbed by Ben Sasse and Meghan McCain's "America's Extremist Abortion Industry" (op-ed, March 11). There is no such thing as infanticide in medical care-I can tell you, as a doctor, that it doesn't happen and it is already illegal. The charges the authors make are entirely untrue. The truth is that abortions that occur after 24 weeks-which is approximately when viability occurs in a normal pregnancy-are exceedingly rare. Well under 1% occur after that point, and when it does happen, it's because a woman's health is in danger, or there is a severe fetal diagnosis. I have treated women in these deeply painful circumstances. These are extremely complex medical situations, and politicians have no role in the physician-patient relationship. We must call out the Sasse-McCain article for what it is: an attempt to take away the right to safe, legal abortion. The consequence of their false claims is grave harm to women's health and permanent erosion of patient rights.

title: Calpers Gives New Private-Equity Plan Tentative Thumbs-Up
summary: Pension board approved the concept for two new captive private-equity vehicles. The national's largest pension fund is moving forward with a plan to fund two new captive private-equity vehicles.

title: Flower Delivery Firm FTD Says It Could Go Out of Business by Summer

title: What Makes This Soup So Good?
summary: Smoky Spanish sausage lends rich flavor to the broth-and a vital link to tradition in a West Virginia community. These recipes make the most of ingredients that have sustained generations in the Mountain State. THIS IS JUST LIKE religion to me. That's how I think about it," Jim Golden said, sitting on his tin-roofed porch overlooking the Buckhannon River in north-central West Virginia. It was early December and Mr. Golden, a retired restaurateur and firearms salesman, was kicking off an annual early-winter rite: the two-day process of making the Spanish blood sausage morcilla. He tied on a black apron, opened a can of lager and took a sip. Then he began feeding slabs of lily-white pork fat through a 1970s-era Cuisinart grinder.

summary: At the U.N. as in Latin America, Beijing's money outweighs morality.. But weakening demand in the key market of China and a consumer shift away from sedans are denting the luxury brand's performance.

title: Sears Shoppers, Workers Lament Its Demise
summary: WSJ readers recall Prodigy internet service and Lands' End; lost trust and 'shoddy products'. Reader response to The Wall Street Journal's article about the undoing of Sears Holdings Corp. shows how deeply the company was embedded in the fabric of America and how pained consumers and former employees are by its unraveling.

title: Somebody Call a Sturgeon! Caviar Prices Are Flatlining
summary: China has become one of the world's largest producers of caviar and it is driving global prices down. Caviar prices are sinking as fish eggs cultivated in China are flooding the global market for what used to be a rare delicacy.

title: Cboe Abandons Bitcoin Futures
summary: Market launched with fanfare in 2017 will wind down once its last contract expires in June. The first U.S. exchange company to launch bitcoin futures has pulled the plug on them, the latest sign that mainstream financial firms are losing their enthusiasm for cryptocurrencies.

title: Majority of New Yorkers Say Amazon's Pullout Bad for State, Poll Finds
summary: Poll finds 61% supported tech company's plan to open headquarters in Long Island City. Two thirds of New Yorkers view Amazon.com Inc.'s decision to scuttle a planned corporate headquarters in Queens as bad for the state, a poll released Monday showed.

title: Petrochemical Fire Near Houston Continues to Spread Monday
summary: Storage tanks containing petrochemical xylene and oil byproduct naphtha burn in Deer Park, Texas. A large fire that broke out Sunday morning at a petrochemical storage facility near Houston continued to spread Monday morning.

title: An Oral History of David Bailey, the Legendary London-Born Photographer Who Reinvented Portraiture
summary: Bailey, whose work defined the Swinging '60s, is the subject of a new career-spanning, limited-edition monograph from Taschen. In this oral history, friends, collaborators and former subjects reveal the charismatic man behind the lens. John Swannell (Bailey's assistant, 1969-1973): If you wanted to be a rock star in those days, you wanted to be Mick Jagger. If you wanted to be an actor, it was Michael Caine. If you wanted to be a hairdresser, it was Vidal Sassoon. For photography, it was Bailey. So he was my hero. He was instinctive about photography. He just knew what was right. All the other photographers I worked with over the years, they all pretended to be great. He was great. And he was so laid back about it.

summary: Foreign energy majors, including Exxon Mobil, are delaying investments amid an uncertain presidential transition. A contentious political transition in Algeria is creating uncertainty around a number of foreign investment deals in Africa's largest natural gas-producing country.

title: I Love Duke. Please Forgive Me.
summary: Thanks to Zion Williamson, even Duke haters agree the Blue Devils are the most irresistible team in men's college basketball. Yes, it's weird.. March Madness is barreling straight at us, and I'm ashamed. I really like Duke.

title: O'Rourke Raised $6.1 Million in First 24 Hours of Campaign
summary: Launch total is the most any 2020 candidate has announced so far. WASHINGTON-Former Texas Rep. Beto O'Rourke raised $6.1 million in the first 24 hours of his presidential campaign, the largest launch haul announced by any candidate so far this cycle.

title: In Tug of War With China, Taiwan Fights to Avoid Being Deserted in the Pacific
summary: President Tsai Ing-wen's eight-day trip features stops in Palau, Nauru and the Marshall Islands. summary: Shoppable ads offer a new avenue of growth for image-heavy internet platforms. They say a picture is worth a thousand words. It also could be worth a lot of money-especially for the world's largest internet companies.

title: AI Pioneer Fei-Fei Li on Building Benevolent Machines
summary: The co-director of the new Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence shares her outlook for the AI age. Stanford University computer science professor Fei-Fei Li worries about the lack of diversity in artificial intelligence development. Today, the pioneering AI researcher is bringing together economists, philosophers, ethicists, legal scholars, historians, psychologists and even artists to develop AI technologies and applications.

title: Lyft Seeks Valuation of Up to $23 Billion in IPO
summary: Ride-hailing service opens hotly anticipated season for tech startups. Lyft Inc. is pegging its valuation at between $21 billion and $23 billion as the ride-hailing service kicks off the roadshow to market its initial public offering Monday.

title: Facebook's Localized Aggregator Has a Problem: Not Enough Local News
summary: One-third of Americans live in a place where the social network can't find enough local news to feed its aggregator. Facebook Inc. has been looking to boost its local-news offerings since a 2017 survey showed most of its users were clamoring for more.

title: Startups Aim to Overhaul Trading in Treasury Bonds
summary: New trading platforms aim to reshape $15 trillion market, letting investors shop around for better prices. A handful of startup trading platforms is trying to reshape the $15 trillion U.S. Treasurys market.

summary: Resume Subscription. Generals, the saying goes, always fight the last war. Chinese exports held up well in 2018 partly thanks to a vertiginous drop in the currency. title: Obvious Ventures Aims to Surpass Impact Investing Model
summary: Twitter co-founder Evan Williams looks to position his team to use its sustainability origins as springboard for success. Partners at Obvious Ventures get touchy about people calling them "impact investors."

title: 'We Need a Plan ASAP'-Cuomo Sends MTA Scrambling to Clean Tunnels
summary: Emails show how the New York governor wields significant power over transportation authority leadership. Last fall New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo expressed dissatisfaction to Metropolitan Transportation Authority executives with the cleanliness of their two road tunnels. His discontent sent MTA officials scrambling to devise a plan to more thoroughly wash the tubes.

title: U.S. Military Now Preparing to Leave as Many as 1,000 Troops in Syria
summary: New estimate-half of current presence-comes three months after President Trump's sought complete withdrawal; proposal would allow continued partnering with Kurdish forces, defying Turkey. WASHINGTON-The U.S. military is crafting plans to keep nearly 1,000 forces in Syria, U.S. officials said, a shift that comes three months after President Trump ordered a complete withdrawal and is far more than the White House originally intended.

title: Is Now the Time for Active Investing to Make a Comeback?
summary: Lower fees and rising volatility are making active management more competitive, supporters say. But critics say the odds are on the side of passive investing.. Few rifts in the world of mutual funds are as pronounced as the one dividing advocates of active management from those of index, or passive, investing.

title: Should You Tell Your Teenager How Much Money You Make?
summary: Parents' salaries are an important element in children's financial education, some say. But others argue that telling your teen what you make can do more harm than good.. Conversations about money are often awkward under the best of circumstances, even among adults. Throw in the difficulties that many parents and teens encounter in communicating openly with each other about nearly any sensitive topic, and the thought of talking to your teenager about money can be daunting. Make it personal-talking to your teenager about your salary, something you may never have revealed to anyone except your spouse or partner-and your anxiety might climb to another level.

title: Should All College Admissions Become Need-Blind?
summary: Proponents say ending ability to pay as an admissions factor will restore trust in higher ed. Opponents say need-blind admissions is great in theory, but would do real damage.. The idea of need-blind college admissions is simple: Applicants are accepted or denied entry based on their merits, not on their ability to pay the tuition bill.

title: Does It Pay, Taxwise, to Get Married?
summary: The new tax code changed the marriage penalty, but didn't do away with it entirely. Among many things, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 affected the so-called marriage penalty, which occurs when a couple's total tax bill rises as a result of getting married and filing their taxes jointly.

title: Do Most People Need a Broker When Selling Their Home?
summary: Some experts say brokers bring deep knowledge to their role as advocate and voice of reason. Others say sellers can handle plenty of broker services by themselves these days.. Selling a house is a big deal. Literally. For many Americans, it's the single-biggest type of business transaction they will ever conduct. Multiple parties get involved, and hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars are on the line.

title: In New Zealand Mosque Massacre, No Exit and Gunman at the Door
